Study of Wolffia globosa (9910) aims to study the effects of altered gravity conditions on the growth and morphology of the plant species . Using random positioning machines and large-diameter centrifuges, we simulated microgravity, partial gravity (Moon), and hypergravity conditions .

Plant material was surface sterilised with 0.3% bleach/water solution for 5min . Plant material has been transferred under a laminar flow hood in sets of 6-well plates . Each plate was filled with 5ml of N-medium solution and sealed with micropore® tape . Experiment was conducted at 30 ± C average temperature with a photoper  The experimental hardware can be 3D printed in any plastic material . The inner dimension of each experimental hardware is designed to fit a multiwell plate of standard dimensions . The prototype of the experimental hardware has been built in plywood .

The study encompassed four different gravity treatments: simulated microgravity, simulated partial gravity (Moon), simulated hypergravity, and two levels of hypergravity . A control group under Earth gravity conditions was included for comparison (Fig. 3) The different images show the different hardware implementation of the different experimental hardware .

Figure 1: Simulated microgravity (sim-µg) simulated by Random Positioning Machine (RPM) RPM simulated partial gravity (Moon) simulated micro gravity (Sim-Moon) and simulated microgravity . Figure 2: 2:g and 4:g, corresponding to twice and four times the gravitational force on Earth, respectively . They were subjected to a gravity level of 2 g, 4 g and 2 g .

The graph shows the calculated doubling time-based on the RGR expressed in the different gravity levels . Data refer to means ± SD of the means N = 12 . Analysis of the morphological characteristics of Wolffia globosa fronds revealed differences in frond length among the gravity treatments .
The study shed light on the response of Wolffia globosa to altered gravitational conditions . The findings present exciting opportunities for further exploration and potential applications .

Hypergravity treatments manifest an increasing (although not statistically significant) trend in growth rates compared to the control treatment . Other results suggest that hypergravity might not affect growth .

The study found that the fronds of Wolffia globosa were most extended in the 1 g treatment, both on the front and back sides . The sim-µg treatment resulted in the most elongated frond shape, followed by the sim-Moon g, 1g, 2g, and 4g treatments . These findings further appraise the possible use of <
